title: Top mount Airtripper for 5:1 geared nema 17 stepper

description.text: I made some changes to the AriTripper v3 extruder. I enalbled it to be mounted at the top of my mendel max. I also changed the m4 nut for a m4 rivet nut. Finally, i made it compatible with the 5:1 planetary geared stepper from phidgets. http://www.phidgets.com/products.php?category=23&product_id=3325_0 The only part that changed was the main body. everything else is the same. I'm using the TL hobbed gear with 8mm ID as it fits the motor shaft. If you want to mount two, i recommend printing the regular and mirrored version that i posted. Let me know if you have any questions. printed at .25mm layer height, 30% infill, 2 shells, no support.

comments.text: How did you connect the planetary gear to the main body? Is it even mounted to the extruder, or are the two separately mounted to your printer frame? My planetary drive has 4 mounting holes spaced 20mm apart, but I don't see how that would align with this model. Nice work, though, I hope to try using this!
comments.author: petermetzger

comments.text: the steppers i am using have the hole circle diameter at 28mm. There are mounting holes in the part to use three of those.
comments.author: petermetzger

comments.text: Ah. I see now. And those three screws, do they support the full weight of the stepper? Or is the printer frame taking some of the load?
comments.author: RatInDaHat

comments.text: They support the stepper fully.
comments.author: petermetzger

comments.text: How is the geared motor treating you in general? Do you recommend it?
comments.author: Sungod3k

comments.text: IT seems to work pretty well. The issue i have, which i think might be motor based, is retraction speed is not fast enough to release the pressure in the hotend when i am changing layers so i always get a little but of extra material when the head stops. IF i up the acceleration then the motor makes fun noises and doesn't retract. So it is a bit of a tradeoff.
comments.author: Sungod3k

comments.text: Yeah I had the same issue with a discontinued geared pollin, to then point where it didnt noticebly retract in any setting. what the max retraction speed you can get out of it?
comments.author: RatInDaHat

comments.text: i have the max speed at 200mm/s, max accel at 200mm/s^2 and jerk at  0.3

comments.text: Accel for the extruder i recall being an issue, but it has been so long since i calibrated all of this that maybe i need to do some test prints again. it might be way too low and that could be from a update to my firmware and i never fixed it. I'll playwith that soon as i need to print some parts anyway. if i can up it, that should hopefully help with the blobs a bit.

The extruder fan on the Davinci is not the most efficient thing in the world, so I made a shroud to make what little it does more effective. UPDATE
The Extended Version replaces the finger-guard and screws into place using those screws, this stops all the escaping air and gives a much better look to the installation. You don't need to unscrew anything for the normal shroud, it just slides on (might need trimming around the fan hole, depends how accurate your print is!) There is also a hole above the filament stepper motor that needs blocking, or as you can see in some of my photos you can put another 5v fan there and wire it in parallel to the normal fan. The stock fan blows air over the extruder heatsink then down onto the part, there is actually a moderate amount of ducting to guide the air onto the part, so I am playing with a centrifugal fan blowing through the top of the extruder over the stepper motor. There is actually quite a lot of air blowing through there now... Lets see if I can actually use it as a layer fan if it is controlled properly! There are some other extruder fan shrouds on thingiverse, I haven't copied them, in fact they are what has persuaded me to make my own (I want to keep this very simple to make and install) equally I wouldn't say this is better than any other on here (actually there are some that look really good, but turn the air flow around, try http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:824926 for more info) we are all learning to make this cheap printer better! Any feedback welcome!
It's a very simple print, no additional cooling needed!

comments.author: tarantulae99

comments.text:
Just a friendly comment. A lot of people fall into this trap - they think that more forced air layer cooling is always better. Unfortunately, with most thermoplastics - especially ABS - it just ain't so.
To get a little better idea of why, try Goggling "don't use a layer cooling fan with ABS".
comments.author: KDan

comments.text: Well, yes and no... The only way I could get Marvin to print in ABS for 3d hubs was with a huge amount of airflow - I then of course had to turn up the extruder temperature to stop de-lamination. Mostly this is useful for small models though, large models have plenty of time between layers to cool off. That's my quandary really, if a large model prints well because it has a chance to cool between layers, how do I accelerate that? So far I'm finding its a balancing act of trial and error!
comments.author: KDan

comments.text: Ahh, Marvin. That part is sort of a special case. The hook on top gives people fits. The steep overhangs on each side are also trouble spots.
comments.author: charliepsycho

comments.text: Yeah, Marvin taught me a lot! Apart from the loop, the main issue I had was between the legs where the bridging would just fall apart. Mostly I solved it with large amounts of airflow (either layer fan or the fans in the side of the enclosure, they both worked) then I learnt the lesson of layer adhesion. But I was determined to be able to print 1 Marvin on his own!
comments.author: KDan

comments.text: I looked at the Ultimaker 2 also when I was looking for a printer at work.  I liked the large print volume, but that thing is way overpriced - especially for a single extruder machine.
comments.author: charliepsycho

comments.text: Ah, interesting. I've been looking at the FlashForge Dreamer, what puts me off is the print volume and the print speed. I'm of the opinion that to get high speed it needs to be a Bowden extruder with as simple and lightweight a print head as possible. Which was why I liked the look of Ultimaker 2. Getting the stiffness in the head transport by using crossing poles is very clever!
comments.author: KDan

title: Model Paint shelving unit
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is not 100 percent complete yet All parts where made in Tnkercad This is a modular system, and you can have as many shelves as you like, i have tried to create this so that all you need are 4 metal rods to keep the units together.( I have super glued them into the holes on the units) there are different shelves for different paint manufactures 28 x 28 for the vallejo dropper bottles 34 x 34 for Humberol paint tins 39 x 39 for Tamyia 10ml paint/AK 35ml Filters/Vallejo 35ml model/Vallejo 60ml bottles washes. 44 x 44 for Tamyia (I think 30 or 35ml bottles) and Humberol
weathering powders and washes I have not tried any other paint combinations so it may work with other manufactures. So far i have created 3 shelves i an going to go to 5 at least then put the top on it. the large 60ml bottles will not fit between the shelving units so if you wish to add this you will need to make the gap bigger between the shelves or as i will be doing is putting them on the top. also i will be drilling 2 holes in the front and adding a metal handle so it will be easier to pull out and put back in. Feedback is welcome regards Paul

The parts where created on a Duplicator 4 using ABS plastic  
Metal rod purchased from my local hobby store  
0.4mm print   
3 hours for the shelving units  
6 hours for the Frame

title: E3D V6 Velleman K8200 & 3Drag extruder holder including 40mm fan-mount

description.text:
Yes - another E3D V6 holder. Somehow all the others did not meet my requirements on sturdiness. So with this one you can use it without changing anything on the extruder base I have lowered the fan, so that a) I get the max. flow on the lower end of the cooling fins and I have maximised the flow diameter. As such with this design the lowest fin is very COLD! Hence there must be a extremely good and very steep heat gradient in the heat brake. b) It is that good, that I can retract the filament without heating up the extruder, even though that is not recommended. Another little goodness in this design is that I can sill use my much liked gears cover. In the appended general arrangement you can see that there is still ample space.
++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
Update
++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
I have made an update as there was still some material in places there should not be. Now even better holding capability

Nothing special, except that I designed it for quite a tight fit. You might need to do a slight amount of filing/sanding to get the best fit. I always like things to fit not being wobbly. Infill 25% will do and use ABS - it is better for this part. This thing was my Inspiration: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:832237

comments.author: Guest

comments.text: Also, for those who complain it doesn't have a heated bed. It would take maybe an hour at most to add the 8x8 (~ 210 X 210 mm) standard heated bed from Ultimachine or any other RepRap parts house. That standard heated bed PCB is the right size, you just need a 10 amp 12 volt supply and a relay to run it. Total cost is like $100 by the time you get a power supply, PCB $50 (Ultimachine), relay $5 (free in my junk bin), kapton 8x8 surface $13.50 (Makergear), don't forget a thermistor $2.75, power supply, and some wiring. Ramps should be able to support it but I would put a relay for power since mine does draw 8+amps when cold! The stock Ultimaker power supply will fail or shutdown if you tried it alone!!! The 8 X * heated bed draws nearly 100 watts by itself (12V times 8.5 Amps = 102 watts)!!!!
comments.author: twotimes

comments.text: You might be right that the stock ultirouter power supply will not be able to supply a heated bed too. But you probably missed that the ultimaker is run at ~20V and probably will withstand 35V. You will need to recalibrate the PID parameters for the nozzle and heated bed if you try 35V, so it is not for the faint of heart. At such voltages, you need less amps for the same power, which is good, because the 2.5mm dc plug is not suited for many amps.
comments.author: Unknown

comments.text: Ok right, higher voltage means you could use less amperage to reach the same wattage (basic Ohm's law), but there is one major catch-that the resistance of the heaters must be changed. The motors work fine BC they have active current regulation-but even then, you always must oversize the power source. With any PWM, the load is directly connected to the source for short periods of time. With an inductor-the voltage/current rise is slow so PWM doesn't present the "full" load (coils direct resistance) what you get is complex impedance. A resistive load does not follow the same principals and thus, if you have a 2.5 ohm heater-it's 2.5 ohms all the time meaning directly divide the voltage by the resistance = peak current no matter what. PWMing a heater still requires a power supply capable of running the heater constantly (in other word must meet or exceed the required current). You will smoke the supply if you use a Reprap heaterboard (the most common available today)as it's resistance is too low for higher voltages. Possibly cutting traces and converting sections to series resistance rather than the current parallel configuration etched into the board. Not impossible, but not plug-n-play either.
comments.author: JelleBoomstra

comments.text: That's cool, I'd love to see a video of it in action (not YouTube please! It doesn't work in China).
comments.author: twotimes

comments.text: This video will probably work (not youtube): http://www.fablab.nl/articles/2011/02/25/ultimaker-in-de-wereld-draait-doorhttp://www.fablab.nl/articles/... (Ultimaker part starts at 6 minutes, the print at 12:40 minutes)

title: Lower Frame Led Mount & Catured Nut

description.text:
Okay so after playing with the Peon230 I have had a few touches with Terra Firma... With the original I would have to remove some of my equipment to get to the screws that held my arms on.  
I decided to reverse the design and put the nuts in the frame allowing me to just unscrew the damaged arm and replace it.

Get some regular 3MM and melt them into the frame to make sure that they are secured and well seated.  
I got a longer 3MM screw and pushed it through the frame the n heated it for a few second with a small blow torch then pulled the nut up to the surface of the frame, then I placed it top down on the tabel making the nut perfectly flush with the top.

title: Kossel Mount for Raspberry Pi Camera

description.text: This is a Kossel frame mount for the Raspberry Pi camera (mine has 2 IR emitters but clamping is on the main camera board). There are 5 parts in total: Two interlocking clips wedge onto the frame and the half-lap joints lock securely without screws. The camera arm connects via a dovetail joint and has notches for the top frame, which comes in two parts, providing locked height adjustment. These are joined by one M3*6mm screw allowing camera rotation. This set up complements: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:856344

description.text: Allows a large filament spool to be used on a Fabtotum fabricator. This is a respin of shomar's excellent one at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:649462, but I had some parts from an old inkjet printer on hand, so I used one of the rods from that printer which are smaller than the one that shomar designed for. Also includes the scad files to allow you to specify the diameter of any rod you might have on hand.

Find a rod, change the "rodDiameter" value in SpoolStandAssembly.scad to match the diameter of the rod.  
It is set up for a standard 608 bearing for rollerblades/skateboards. You can order these online from ebay or amazon.  
Snap one half of each stand side onto the bearing and then press the assembled stand halfs plus bearing into the base. Slide your metal rod through the hole. Mine was a little tight so I drilled the hole a little larger.  
If you use the same type of rod that I did, the rubber rings that were used to move the paper though the inkjet printer are removable and can be fitted on either side of each stand assembly to stabilize the stands position on the rod.

A simple solid, there is nothing complicated about this classic cut gem design. But with its seven facets it serves as the "age stone" for a 7-year birthday party. Of course, seven is a special number being the number of days in a week, the number of celestial bodies (in classic astrology), the number of metals (in traditional alchemy), and so on.
As this was popular here I made additional versions, so 5-, 6-, 8-, and 9- year versions are now available.
This needs no raft and no supports. Scale it to whatever size you wish.

title: RepRapDiscount Smart LCD Controller Support for Prusa i3

description.text:
UPDATE
The official LCD support for the original Josef Prusa i3 kit (not MK2)! This is a RepRapDiscount Smart LCD Controller support originally designed for a Prusa i3 kit from Voxel Factory (an EiNSTeiN variant of the 3D printer). The threaded rods are 10mm, don't hesitate to ask for a custom bracket. The good news (or bad) is that there is no other material than plastic.

description.header: Show your make and remix please...

description.text: See Prusa i3 Plus kit assembly - 6. LCD for a complete visual assembly guide.

You'll need to extend the ribbon cables before installing the LCD at the front of the printer. Right now, the cables I'm using are 60cm long each, the panel is still functionnal.  
Slide the brackets on each side of the printed circuit board (PCB) on the rear side, open holes faceup. Insert the PCB into the cover while aligning the brackets with the slots. The inside of the slots and the surfaces of the brackets must to be clean.  
The brackets then snaps on the threaded rods at the front of the Y carriage.

description.text:
here is a cool math art sculpture I made in Rhino-cad (no grasshopper or plugins) its based on one shape, a minimal surface of a tetrahedron spun and rotated, rinse repeat. this was part of an exploration to create a nice looking gyroid I could use for more complex boolean stuff, but this one fairs quite well also! UPDATE:
after research i've found I've stumbled across something very similar to a triply periodic minimal surface (tpms), but not exactly. the closest one I could find is the Schwars D surface. perhaps this is a variation. If anyone knows exactly what the underlying shape is it would be much appreciated...
i recommend printing with a bit of support. if you can control the angle, print supports on everything 70 degrees from parallel to the bed (90 is horizontal)

This generates joined wing sections. Each wing section is described at the root and tip.with the X,Y,Z,Chord and rotation in space. A NACA airfoil profile is then swept from root to tip with the NACA asym profile. I did it as a  planform generator to build ribs and internal components. It may be a bit much for Openscad.  
See Wikipedia NACA Airfoil 4 digi profile for the math. The binding of the sections is in the XY plane.   
Someone else associated with Openscad generated the sweep.scad file. I would like to give credit but don't know who it was.

description.text: I seen one here somewhere and I though I can do that too. Created with Design Spark Mechanical, a FREE and extremity easy to learn and use CAD http://www.rs-online.com/designspark/electronics/eng/page/mechanical Have a great day. :-)

The EnteraLite Infinity is a pump for some children that are fed through a stomach tube.  Unfortunately, some times the pump must be placed within reach of inquisitive fingers (such as the tube to the stomach is not being long enough).  The pump has no lock-out features; so the inquisitive fingers can have great fun mashing buttons, shutting off the pump, or changing the flow rate - all of which can have very negative impacts.  
This guard allows the caregiver to slide the guard up, start a feeding program, then secure the guard in place and tighten the screws.  This keeps the buttons safe from the little fingers.  
It uses 1/4-20 hardware (nuts, bolts, washers) to clamp around the IV pole and secure the guard.

comments.text:
I've got a Scottoiler system on my chain bike & have been wondering if I should go for a double nozzle. The current single nozzle is working just fine in general, but especially in difficult circumstances it can get clogged - I've had that once or twice now,
With a thing like this, you've got a 2nd nozzle still feeding the chain.
comments.author: Harry_D60

comments.text: If I remember correctly the Scottoilers narrow nozzle holds back the oil to stop drips when engine is off.  The loobman uses a dose system so when you press button 3 to 5ml of oil (I use engine oil) is fed into tube which runs out onto sprocket within very short time, so can be used when setting off or at a junction etc.  Maybe the scottoil will still hold back with this nozzle too. When you give it a go maybe you could setup up a bit of a test rig before fitting to bike. If it should keep dripping I'd try smaller tube inside the original tube next to nozzle to slow it down.  Hope it works and let me know how it goes.

remixed_from.title: Eye One Xtreme - custom battery tray incl. receiver/rx attachment back-plate

title: EOX GeForce 1300 battery and Mobius tray

description.text: Tray that keeps your GeForce 1300 battery snug while holding your Mobius camera

I make everything that needs any kind of strength anymore with PETG. It's just that much better than anything else. Obviously the Larger tray needs support to print properly. The part that holds the Mobius camera is taken "as is" from Arakon's design. All I did was to make up the battery tray and fuse everything together to make a mount for the EOX. Two Zip ties and the battery tray is mounted to the stock frame or the Poly frame securely. I highly recommend using a zip tie to secure the Mobius to it's tray. Finally, you need 4 Vibration Damping Balls (100g). They're easy enough to find... If your landing legs aren't long enough, use the longest ones from here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:810081 Also, the picture is an earlier design, but you can see what the actual finished top part looks like in the preview of the stl file. Added two pictures with the latest design and without the Mobius attached. Note that you need a small piece of foam between the battery and the side that the camera would be on to make up for the size of the battery side of the dampeners.

remixed_from.title: Printrbot LC and LC+: Y Bearing Guide for GT2 32 teeth pulleys

title: Printrbot LC and LC+: Y Bearing Guide for GT2 32 teeth pulleys DERIVATIVE

description.text:
I printed the "Printrbot LC and LC+: Y Bearing Guide for GT2 32 teeth pulleys" by gyronictonic, and had to make a modification to the end as it hit the zip ties that are used to hold the Y-Bearings (picture of printed part is the original with the sanded end) This derivative shortens the end so you do not need to sand it down. The center clearance for the pulley is also made larger to 15mm in the derivative. Credit Where Credit is Due:
I have to say the original design is a great concept and give all the credit to Gyronictonic.

Download: -The original "Y_bearing_roof.STL" (I have uploaded a copy of the file)
  • New derivative part "13-127_Y-Bearing_Guide_GT2_32_Teeth_Derivative"
    • Go here (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:29687) and read the "Instructions" before considering this mod, and the comment by Plexus before assembling. Hardware Note:
    I was able to get M8 x 12mm button head allen bolts to thread all of the way in and still clear the bearings. The bolts are 1.25mm pitch. Assembly Order:
  • Install "13-127_Y-Bearing_Guide_GT2_32_Teeth_Derivative".
  • Install Pulley
  • Install Y_bearing_roof

This is a toy bus that actually rolls.  It prints as a frame, windows, bumpers, and wheels, so that it can be printed in three different colors of PLA.  
For this model, I used 8-32 philips-head machine screws (3/4" long), 12 washers, and 4 8-32 hex nuts to secure the wheels so that they roll.  I put a drop of LocTite blue threadlock on the threads to keep the nuts from coming loose accidentally.  The windows and bumpers were attached with superglue.  
It was designed for use in a brain-injury support group that is working on relearning life skills (such as riding a bus).

This file describes a parametric ball and socket mount that could be used to position a small, lightweight object at  a specific angle (e.g. a touch-on LED closet light that is aimed at an object of interest).  
The socket has screw holes for attaching to a substrate like a wall or door.  Objects could be attached to the ball mount with Velcro or adhesive.  
It uses  a 10-32 thumbscrew to apply pressure to the ball to keep it from moving, with the extant hole drilled with a 3/16" bit..  I am using   McMaster-Carr Item#: 91185A386  
The file has an option for a dimpled "golf-ball-esque" look  that makes it lock into place easier.

description.text: SeeMeCNC.com makes one of the best pinch extruders out there. It handles 3mm and 1,75mm but by default comes with the 1.75mm setup. With these parts you can adapt a 3mm bowden tube connector. It doesn't require any tools so you can switch back to 1.75 easily.

Extruder kit:
http://shop.seemecnc.com/Direct-to-Bowden-Conversion-kit-for-Steves-Extruder-Hotend-10111.htm Bowden adapter: http://shop.seemecnc.com/Direct-to-Bowden-Conversion-kit-for-Steves-Extruder-Hotend-10111.htm and the 3mm connector:
http://shop.seemecnc.com/Push-To-Connect-Fitting-for-6mm-OD-Tube-38831.htm?categoryId=-1 Print the SeeMeCNC extruder mount: -Screw 3mm bowden connector into the nut.
-Slide the peg up through the extruder bowden plate and twist the nut on.
-Bolt the extruder plate onto the extruder on the side for 3mm.
-Mount to the printed extruder Ultimaker bracket
-Wire up (I made quick disconnects so I could go back to stock) IMPORTANT:
This extruder extrudes in reverse of the stock one so you need to edit your marlin configuration file.. the following line should be "true" define INVERT_E0_DIR true // for direct drive extruder v9 set to true, for geared extruder set to false Run Cura first run wizard to calibrate. Mount the

comments.text: OK... I take that back... the extruder is awesome until it fails. Then there is little you can do about it. The problem with the extruder is if the bolts loosen up the plastic compression gears will slip. If you don't catch it on a long print they grind away. Sigh... had to go back to my Ultimaker extruder which isn't much better.

description.text:
This clamp is designed for wheelchairs such as the Quickie Ti which are made from 1" tubing. The clamp is designed to attach to tubing that has a 3" bend radius. The clamp (in two parts), once assembled, will position an eyebolt (or other threaded fastener) at a specific location. This can make it easier to transport items (such as a bag), act as a tool holder, etc. This model uses the following hardware:
3/8" - 4" Eyebolt
3/8" - hex nut
(5) 1/4"-20 - 2" Bolts
(5) 1/4"-20 - Hex Nuts or Hex Stop Nuts
(5) 1/4"-20 - flat washers Foam rubber shelf liner is wrapped around the tube to prevent scuffing and to increase the grip on the clamp. There are two designs - one with two eyebolt sockets and one with three. The three has not actually been made, as the two-socket variant was enough for our purposes. This should only be used for light duty loads - it should NOT be used as a wheelchair tie-down in a vehicle.

This clamp is designed for wheelchairs such as the Quickie Ti which are made from 1" tubing. The clamp is designed to attach to straight tubing, dowels, etc. The clamp (in two parts), once assembled, will position an eyebolt (or other threaded fastener) at a specific location. This can make it easier to transport items (such as a bag), act as a tool holder, etc. This model uses the following hardware:
3/8" - 4" Eyebolt
3/8" - hex nut
(4) 1/4"-20 - 1.5" Bolts
(4) 1/4"-20 - Hex Nuts or Hex Stop Nuts
(4) 1/4"-20 - flat washers Foam rubber shelf liner is wrapped around the tube to prevent scuffing and to increase the grip on the clamp. This should only be used for light duty loads - it should NOT be used as a wheelchair tie-down in a vehicle.

author: negasaurus

description.text:
Two icons of the twentieth century!  
The Saturn V Apollo moon rocket - everyone who was watching remembers.  
And the humble ball-point pen, introduced to the public in the early 1900s, became so ubiquitous we didn't even think about it - it was a part of the landscape, everywhere. But it seems to be fading in the digital age, as pocket protectors have given way to smart phones.

Remove the 3 structural supports from each part, and otherwise trim as needed. (Cura's auto-generated brim was not sufficient to prevent parts from breaking away during print, so I added these supports.)  
Remove the ink cartridge from an inexpensive ball-point pen and insert it into the rocket's lower stage, leaving the writing tip exposed. Place the rocket's upper stage over the writing tip. Align the locking tabs, press the stages together, and twist to lock. Place the rocket's escape module over the writing tip.

description.text:
The pulley I used on the Y motor is a 16 teeth pulley. When using the stock Rework or https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:745934 and the bed moves towards a minimum or maximum position, a lot of tension does occur. This is due to the big 608zz bearing on the y-idler (Prusa i3 Rework stock). I prolonged one doodad/pylon/whatever so it's better on par with the pulley. Works very well in combination with http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:856725
-> Replaceing the 608zz bearing in the Rework vanilla when using 16 teeth y-pulleys.
I have included the moveable part from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:745934 for consistency.

description.text:
Parametric Rubik's Cube 3x3 (60 mm). Following parameters can be used to vary the dimensions of the cube:
size = 60.5; Needed Parts for building a single cube:
  • Each part is needed exactly once to build the cube
  • Screw M3x20 (6x)
  • Washer M3, diameter 5.8 mm (6x)
    • remark:
  • In case the "size" parameter has been changed, a different screw length will be required.
  • The Cube has been printed both in PLA and ABS. The ABS version so far seems to turn much smoother.
  • for a 75 mm version of this design see:
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:880247

• Support structures are needed to print the pieces. The STL's are positioned in the correct position to be printed.

  • 20% infill works fine.

  • It is recommended to use ABS, the assembled cube turns much smoother.

  • It is recommended to drill the small hole of the Cube_MidPiece to a diameter of 3.5 mm and the big hole to a diameter of 7.0 mm (depth = 6.5 mm).

  • It is recommended to drill the small hole of the Cube_CenterPiece to a diameter of 2.5 mm

Simple case for the Fitbit Flex.  Designed to be simply carried in your pocket.  
I don't like to wear my Fitbit on my wrist or on a clip/fob.  I used to carry the wrist band mount in my pocket which often got in the way of other things.  And the "bare" Fitbit is rather small to be by itself in my pocket, and also exposes the contacts.  So, I created this case.

Do not print this with supports - the retention "spring"/tab which holds the Fitbit in place needs the lower gap in order to flex and allow the fitbit to snap into the case.  There are 0.5mm supports which is part of the file - these should be enough to bridge the gap.  You may have to clean these out before you use the case.  
I used 70% fill on mine.  You may be able to get by with less - I was just worried about having enough material in the "spring" to remain intact during flexing.  Also, I used ABS, which has a bit of flexibility.  I have not tried printing this with PLA (which seems to be a lot stiffer than ABS), so I don't know how the spring will perform with this material.  
It may be difficult at first to get the Fitbit into and out of the case due to the stiffness of the springs/tabs.  After you exercise them for a few times it should be easier to get it in/out.

This is something my son and I used as a sun tracker.  The basic idea is that you hot glue four light sensors (we used photo-resistors) in each quadrant, and as the light moves off-center it casts shade on the opposite side.  So maximizing the value of all the sensors will have it point to the brightest spot.  
The design includes slots to drop in the sensors and allow the leads to go out the back.  It also includes a hole down the center, which can be used to calibrate.  (The light coming down the center hole will project  a circle when pointed directly at the light.)  
I've built it at various heights.  A taller one is more sensitive to tiny changes in angle, but can cause a lot of "seeking", while a shorter one is more forgiving but less sensitive.  Black filament works best to avoid reflections.  
I've also included my Arduino sketch which may be a bit of a naive approach, but worked for our purposes.  (This sketch and typical photoreceptors causes quite a bit of "seeking" right around the optimal value...)  
You can test it by hot-gluing two servos together and the sensor to the top one to make a 2-axis tracker, as seen in the photo above.
Best if printed with black filament, 1 shell, 100% infill.

A 20mm long hexagonal cylinder, 6mm across the flats. My MegaPro ratcheting 13-in-1 screwdriver uses double-ended two inch bits. I wanted to use it with some single-ended one inch bits, so I made this drop-in spacer. It is slightly undersized so it won't get stuck in there. Update: It turns out, even while being slightly undersized, there is a chance that if you put enough pressure on the spacer, it will deform and be difficult to remove. It also turns out that one of my earlier designs works just as well for this use case: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:350118

title: Follow Focus Gear - LOMO Prime Lens

description.text: A follow focus gear for LOMO prime lenses designed to replace the original 0.5mm pitch gears with gears that are cinema standard 0.8mm. I never liked the fact that the original LOMO gears have such a thin contact area, so this new design increases that to a full 10mm. There are a few variations in the way these lenses are built, so I have included 3 screw and 4 screw versions of the design, as well as a version that has clearance for the bayonet mount. Using this design in theory should let you install the focus ring without having to remove the lens mount, assuming the original focus ring can be removed in the same way. If removing your lens mount is required for installation and you are not comfortable doing so, take your lens to a professional for installation. Designed with FreeCAD. Source files available on Github: https://github.com/fdiebel/lomo-primes-ff

A simple fox. Ready to print.

Concerned about someone eating eggs you have decorated using non-food safe inks? If so, then these designs may be the ticket! All these designs have a tessellation of skulls. They then incorporate either some short warning text, or a longer text which wraps in a spiral around the egg:
Warning: In keeping with common decency, the Administration of this household would like to point out that the inks deposited upon this egg have not been tested for food safety. Indeed, based solely upon empirical evidence (that being the behavior of some members of this household), the Food Police have deemed these inks to be suspect. Moreover, the band gap energies of the ink's pigments have not been tested by qualified quantum mechanics and as such it remains unknown whether or not they emit photons unsafe for ocular consumption. Please read and/or eat at your own risk!
NOTE BENE: I do not mean to poke fun at anyone concerned about the use of non food safe inks. Not only is it a legitimate concern, I happen to share it as well. I made these designs as I wanted to leave a few of these in the fridge for my wife to come across. Note also that the kind folks at Evil Mad Science have a nice write up of some food safe pens they have tested with the Eggbot. You can read their write up at http://www.evilmadscientist.com/article.php/edibleink

These drawings are 800 x 3200 plots intended for drawing on an Eggbot. Each plot has three layers 1. Draw this layer with or without a pen in order to help you frame the drawing on your egg. This layer just has two small, horizontal lines at x=0 and x=800.

2. This layer contains the skull tiling.

3. This layer contains the warning text.
warning.svg & warning-flipped.svg: the short text warning. The "flipped" version is intended for drawing with the egg's bottom to the egg motor cup. You can get the same effect by reversing both motors on the "Options" tab of the Eggbot Control extension. warning-spiral.svg & warning-spiral-flipped.svg: The long, spiral text warning. Be sure to enable x axis wrapping in the Eggbot Control extension's "Options" panel. warning-spiral-fine.svg & warning-spiral-fine-flipped.svg: The long spiral warning text but with some bold text at the start ("Warning:") and italicized text at the end ("your own risk!"). Since the start and end of the spiral text is drawn near the egg's poles, the text there is drawn a bit small relative to text near the egg's equator. You will need to use a very fine tipped pen in order for the bold and italicized text to appear nicely. A 0.05 mm Copic Multiliner SP, for instance. The photo of the egg with spiral warning text is this variation. Note that when you draw layers 1 or 3, you will notice a pause of close to a minute: this is the Eggbot Control extension making its way through all the skulls looking for the desired layer or other matching layers. Note that the eye sockets and nose cavities are not hatched. They will not plot as filled regions on your eggs. If you wish to hatch them, then feel free to do so. The skull in the upper left corner of the drawing is the skull which is "cloned" everywhere else. So, that's the skull you want to change.

title: "Braq" Jointed Dragon, fixed manifold now all parts with supports

description.text:
I found that the head in the "Braq" Jointed Dragon had way too many manifold errors for slic3r 1.2.6 to handle.
I've since added all of the other parts. I've printed these myself on my RepRap - a modified version of RepRapPro's Ormerod 2 I've repaired the mesh so that slic3r can use it. For directions about assembly see the original http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:854575 I used Netfabb cloud to fix the original STL
http://cloud.netfabb.com/ Info about netfabb cloud:
http://www.netfabb.com/news.php?nid=16 BQ labs thinks they may have fixed the issues with the original head. However, I'll keep this item available, as other parts had issues as well, and I haven't confirmed that the head is actually fixed.

First try on making a multi color fishing fly named "Balsa Wasp". The waps-file is for one color printing. The other two are for multi color printing. The orginal pattern is black and  purple. It should work great with black and yellow also. Try to get as little infill as your printer could handle. It needs air for buoyancy.  I printed with 0% infill. Use some grizzly hackle in front of the body. It is possible to use your slicer to adjust how "fat" and long your wasp is.  
You should use some epoxy glue to attach the body to your fly hook.   
My intension is to print in yellow ABS and then use some acteon vapor to make the modell smooth. After that I will use a permanent black marker to make the rings on the body. The picture of the test print was done in white ABS and then I used yellow paint. Not a good solution, since the permanent marker made the paint goey.

title: Kinect Camera Tripod Mount with Embedded Threaded Insert

description.text: I needed to make a sturdy 3D-printed camera mount for MakerBot's current artist-in-residence Kyle McDonald who is doing work with the Kinect. I found a bunch of 1/4-20 threaded inserts in the BotCave and thought: "Why don't I build this model around this hardware?" I built this part with Tinkercad, a solid modeller, so that I could continue to tweak parts of the model based on my printed tests with relatively tight tolerances. Additional benefit, you can jump in and make your own version of the mount with whatever baroque embellishments appeal to you! Edit the part online at: https://tinkercad.com/p/acc0d8eff4d75895 Rather than aiming to trap the threaded insert in the part mechanically, I designed the model so that I might turn on the extruder after the print has finished and use the nozzle like a hot glue gun to fill in the cavities around the mounting spikes and weld it in so that the hardware cannot shift during use. Also, you can source threaded inserts here: http://www.mcmaster.com/#90975a025/=cbpva0

• Print the body of the mount.
  • Drop in the threaded insert.
  • Turn on the extruder and fix the threaded insert in place by filling the cavities around the mounting spikes.
  • Clean out the countersunk holes on the back for the M3x12mm bolts with a file or screwdriver.
  • Sand away any residual plastic that might interfere with firm, flat mounting.
  • Fasten 4 M3x12 bolts down into the four tiny holes on the Kinect. You should be able to create threads and mount the Kinect reliably. Be gentle when/if you unscrew the bolts such that you can re-use the threads a second time.
  • Research Kyle McDonald's Processing sketches so that you can 3D scan somebody!

description.text:
I needed to check the elevation of a building site to see if it was flood free.
I quickly designed and printed this sight to press onto a spirit level I have.
It is bigger than it needs to be but I won't be taking this any further.
A tripod adapter would be the next step.
This isn't a precision instrument but was good enough to show the site was high enough. The house being sighted is just above flood level and the test site is a little higher.
I repeated the sighting several time including some with the level reversed. I always got the same result within a 1/2 a meter or so.
